description:
"The world is a very small place, but for those who know it...it is very, very large. And the world, when it is viewed by those who 'know'— is far larger than just one world can hold!"

The famous CLAMP brings back the characters from all their creations for an ultimate showdown in this multi-dimensional tale.

This is the story of four travelers, bound by fate and by prophesied future. Sakura is the princess of Clow Country, and possessor of a strange power that promises to change the world. Syaoran is an aspiring archaeologist and her childhood friend. When Sakura is endangered by the plan a certain man has for the future, the princess' memories are scattered across dimensions in the form of feathers, and Syaoran is forced to go on a desperate journey to retrieve them. They are accompanied by Fay D. Flourite, a magician running from the horrible truth of his past, and Kurogane, a rough-mannered ninja trying to get back to his world. However, the ability to cross worlds demands a great price, and each of them must pay the Dimensional Witch with what he or she values most. In order to save his princess, Syaoran must give up his relationship with her. Even if he gathers all of Sakura's memories, she will never remember their past together...

But the world is not so simple. The very moment these four made this decision, their destinies are sealed into a tragic course...as everyone in the group has their own secrets. Visions of the future are seen, and prophesies are made. The cruel future which lies ahead reads only of betrayal, abandonment, devastation and anguish.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Crossover
tags.description: Centers around the placement of two or more otherwise discrete fictional characters, settings, or universes into the context of a single story.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Achronological Order
tags.description: Chapters or episodes do not occur in chronological order.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Boys' Love
tags.description: Prominently features romance between two males, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Vampire
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a vampire.

tags.name: Desert
tags.description: Prominently features a desert environment.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Snowscape
tags.description: Prominently or partially set in a snowy environment.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Cannibalism
tags.description: Prominently features the act of consuming another member of the same species as food.

name.native: ファイ・D・フローライト

node.description: [Website](http://www.clamp-net.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CLAMP_news) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/clamp_4_official/) CLAMP is an all-female Japanese manga artist group that formed in the mid-1980s. It consists of leader [Nanase Ohkawa](https://anilist.co/staff/97292), and three artists who shift roles for each series: [Mokona](https://anilist.co/staff/100802) (もこな), [Tsubaki Nekoi](https://anilist.co/staff/100804), and Satsuki Igarashi (いがらし寒月). Almost 100 million CLAMP tankōbon copies have been sold worldwide as of October 2007. In general, Ohkawa gets her inspiration for the group from everyday events such as dreams or the news. Unlike most manga artists who specialize in a single genre, CLAMP has created a diverse body of work. CLAMP's genres vary widely, from childish and comedic (Cardcaptor Sakura, Clamp School Detectives) to more dramatic and teen-rated (xxxHolic, X) series. Furthermore, drawing from the idea of Osamu Tezuka's Star System as they did in Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, CLAMP often crossover characters from their own series into their other works, which gives rise to a loosely defined "Clamp Universe".

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tiffyshindo) Fédoua Lamodière (formerly Fédoua Thalal) is a French manga translator. She studied Japanese at INALCO from 1998 to 2003, and started translating working as a professional translator in 2001 with Pocket Monsters: PiPiPi★Adventure at Glénat editions. She also works for Pika, Ki-oon, Kaze and Taifu comics. She translated some famous works, such as Dragon Ball, Seven Deadly Sins, Witch Hat Atelier, Jujutsu Kaisen...
Her favourite manga are Dragon Ball, Attack on Titan and Hunter x Hunter.

Alex Pilot is a French realisator and journalist who worked for the channels NoLife and Game One. He produced reports on Japanese pop culture and is married to [Suzuka Aosaka](https://anilist.co/staff/221084/Suzuka-Asaoka)
Suzuka Asaoka is a Japanese to French translator and interpretor. She also worked as a journalist on topics linked to Japan. She is married to [Alex Pilot](https://anilist.co/staff/221083/Alex-Pilot)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Maria_Ferrer) | [Blog](https://lalocatertuliadelte.wordpress.com/) | [Professional website](http://www.traduccionesimposibles.com/)

Maria Ferrer is a translator who can translate several languages to Spanish or Catalan. She is specialized in TV show, Anime and mangas translation.
Claudia Peter is a Japanese to German translator, who also works as a professor on translation and interpretation at the university.
Luiz Octavio Kobayashi is a Japanese to Portuguese translator.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/williamflanagan)

William (Bill) Flanagan started translating manga professionally in 1991 and has been translating and editing manga ever since. He rose to be Director of Editorial of Viz Media in the early 2000s and from then on, has had his hand in top-selling manga. He also translates anime, games, TV, movies and novels. He lives with his wife and son in the mountains of Gifu Prefecture, Japan.
